title: Becassine
author: Becassine
content: With this Atomic wallet hack, I have a lot of questions. For example, how do free wallet developers make money? It's probably a naive question, but in the end, safety also depends on the reliability of the team, and they're not going to work for free.

comments.author: Charles-Tim
comments.body: From instant exchanges, decentralized exchanges and other means they included third parties that their wallet users can make use of, for the third parties to make money from the wallet users.Also some coin developers can pay them to support their coin.No need of creating multiple topics, you could have included this in your recently created topic: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5456558.msg62414136#msg62414136

comments.author: bitmover
comments.body: Quote from: Becassine on June 16, 2023, 12:47:26 PMWith this Atomic wallet hack, I have a lot of questions. For example, how do free wallet developers make money? It's probably a naive question, but in the end, safety also depends on the reliability of the team, and they're not going to work for free.Most free wallets have ads or some kind of partnership with exchanges , like Coinomi wallet.Exchange certainly pay to have those services available in the app, as it is a way to attract customers.

comments.author: safar1980
comments.body: Quote from: Becassine on June 16, 2023, 12:47:26 PMWith this Atomic wallet hack, I have a lot of questions. For example, how do free wallet developers make money? It's probably a naive question, but in the end, safety also depends on the reliability of the team, and they're not going to work for free.The main income comes from affiliate rewards and advertising. There are many opportunities to offer various exchanges, services and even hardware wallets for added security. Or a team invests money in a project to steal the wallet of a large company

comments.author: Charles-Tim
comments.body: Quote from: bitmover on June 16, 2023, 01:04:18 PMMost free wallets have ads or some kind of partnership with exchanges , like Coinomi wallet.It is true that wallet developers can gain from ads, but I have only noticed Mycelium wallet to have ads, others that I have tested out bet did not have ads. Both bitcoin and altcoin wallets. Are there other reputed wallets with ads? In my opinion, it is not good to recommend such wallet. Or what do you think?

comments.author: ImThour
comments.body: So how does Instagram make money? From it's userbase. Similar strategy is used in any *free* product. You are the money for them, the more the userbase, the more information they have and the better sponsors they can get for their product, simple as that. In case of Crypto Wallets, it's maybe that they can advertise a big Crypto coin without looking sus? IDK.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: There are different ways free wallet developer's make money as some has already been stated hereKeeping not selling customers data constantThe most common is through fees generated from swapping tokens or coins in the walletProviding assistance in promoting other coins or tokens in the form of airdrops and they are given their commissionCreating their own native tokensPartnership with other exchanges or platforms Etc

I thought Coinomi used to have ads, but it doesn't anymore as i didn't see one now in my mobile. I use Coinomi (I know it is not the best, but just carry a few 50-100 usd in my phone)Personally, I wouldn't care if some ad show up from time to time in a good mobile wallet. I just want some wallet which allows me receive any coin/token from the main blockchains easily, to transfer money fast. Holding some cryptocurrencies, specially bitcoin, when travelling abroad has been proven be useful for me in the past. Sometimes international bank transfer may take a long time to get completed, and bitcoin is way cheaper and faster

comments.author: BitDane
comments.body: Quote from: Becassine on June 16, 2023, 12:47:26 PMWith this Atomic wallet hack, I have a lot of questions. For example, how do free wallet developers make money? It's probably a naive question, but in the end, safety also depends on the reliability of the team, and they're not going to work for free.If we look at it, it is really an interesting question, I myself really does not know but I do heard that some developers are able to earn through sponsorship.  Others were paid by a company that took interest on their products and pay them to continuously develop the software.  While many were leaving on the donations of people who wanted to give back due to the help of their software.  Aside from that these developers can also offer other services where they can earn money.  Since they have proven their capability on their wallet creation, they can easily convince company that requires services of their expertise.  These developers can also introduce premium services for users that wanted advance features this way developers cam get subscription payment on their wallet.

comments.body: Quote from: ImThour on June 16, 2023, 01:32:59 PMSo how does Instagram make money? From it's userbase. Similar strategy is used in any *free* product. You are the money for them, the more the userbase, the more information they have and the better sponsors they can get for their product, simple as that. In case of Crypto Wallets, it's maybe that they can advertise a big Crypto coin without looking sus? IDK.The actually free crypto wallets have teams that rely on their main job and donations. Believe it or not, people who do this for everyone else and not for personal gains still exist. They’re rarities, but they exist.As you may expect, donations usually aren’t considerable and they’re more like tipping. That’s why they have to rely on other sources of income. I’d guess there are also a few devs who have enough money and passive income to not give a shit about being paid to do fun development stuff.

comments.author: FinneysTrueVision
comments.body: Most wallets have a bunch of unnecessary crap included in them. Almost every altcoin wallet has a Changelly integration or some other sort of instant exchange service. Some wallets are owned by popular exchanges like Coinbase or Binance. They don't necessarily need to make money from their wallet because they already have other sources of revenue, although they usually still include all this other stuff where they collect affiliate commissions and trading fees.Wasabi, Samourai, and Sparrow wallets all have a built in coinjoin mixer where they earn fees. These are a few of the wallets that actually provide a useful service.

comments.author: Adams0001
comments.body: Fees are commonly used in the business strategies of concentrate ones. They charge a set fee for undertaking (some even demand a wage for deposits), then finish transactions for all of their customers in batches, saving on the actual cost of mining fees and keeping the difference.
